componenttext: Okay. And then the other thing is just, could you update us on what you're seeing of total new supply across your portfolio? And I guess, maybe specifically just as you look at the top 5 markets, which I think are comprised of over 50% of your NOI, maybe if you could just drill down a little bit there so L.A., New York, D.C., Boston and San Francisco?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure, thank you, Smedes. So overall, CoStar is reporting about 900 stores to be delivered in 2017 and -- I'm sorry, CBRE, my mistake, and that's as good a number as we can come to. We've looked at 8 of our top markets in depth to try to aggregate as many
componenttext: Sure, thank you, Smedes. So overall, CoStar is reporting about 900 stores to be delivered in 2017 and -- I'm sorry, CBRE, my mistake, and that's as good a number as we can come to. We've looked at 8 of our top markets in depth to try to aggregate as many different data sources, as well as our people on the ground, brokers and our partners, and that accounts to little over 40% of our NOI. And we found 360 stores in those markets that were either newly completed, under construction or in some stage of the planning process. About half of those stores competed with our stores in that market. So we are certainly seeing new deliveries competing with some of our stores, and we're seeing other markets where we don't have the same level of competition. The most difficult thing is of those 360 stores, 135 of them are somewhere in the planning process and we see a significant level of those stores fall out due to inability to get permits or financing or some other reason.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Juan Sanabria with Bank of America.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just following up on that supply question from Smedes is can you help us benchmark that 360? I mean, what -- do you have a sense of what that was at this point last year? And as part of that question, any views on how supply looks at this point for '18 re
componenttext: Just following up on that supply question from Smedes is can you help us benchmark that 360? I mean, what -- do you have a sense of what that was at this point last year? And as part of that question, any views on how supply looks at this point for '18 relative to '17? Do you expect it to be flat, higher or lower?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's a really good question. It varies significantly by market. So for example, if you look at Chicago where we would identify 41 new stores, 23 of those have already been delivered. So you're already deeper into the cycle with more stores delivered than
componenttext: It's a really good question. It varies significantly by market. So for example, if you look at Chicago where we would identify 41 new stores, 23 of those have already been delivered. So you're already deeper into the cycle with more stores delivered than being planned. Dallas is maybe on the other end where we've identified 83 stores and only 39 have been delivered. So it really varies widely by market. Our sense is that there'll be fewer deliveries in 2018 than 2017. Certainly, CBRE believes that as well. I think their number was 400, but time will tell.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just back on the same-store revenue guidance. What are the street rate growth expectations, I guess, as we go through '17? And is there a skew in how -- in the same-store revenue growth over the course of the year? Is it accelerating
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just back on the same-store revenue guidance. What are the street rate growth expectations, I guess, as we go through '17? And is there a skew in how -- in the same-store revenue growth over the course of the year? Is it accelerating or decelerating as the year progresses?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our guidance assumes that it decelerates a little bit more. So you're going to start the year slightly higher than we end the year. And the SmartStop pool actually start a fair amount higher with -- coming up against tougher comps at the end of the year,
componenttext: Our guidance assumes that it decelerates a little bit more. So you're going to start the year slightly higher than we end the year. And the SmartStop pool actually start a fair amount higher with -- coming up against tougher comps at the end of the year, so it will show more deceleration in that particular pool of properties. But overall, slight deceleration.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: And then any color on the street rate growth that you're kind of assuming as the year goes, particularly into peak leasing?
componenttext: And then any color on the street rate growth that you're kind of assuming as the year goes, particularly into peak leasing?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: I would tell you it's going to be 3 to 5. It's going to depend a little bit on strength of the market and your occupancy.
componenttext: I would tell you it's going to be 3 to 5. It's going to depend a little bit on strength of the market and your occupancy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gaurav Mehta with Cantor Fitzgerald.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: So following up on that deceleration comments about same-store revenue throughout 2017, would you expect it to stabilize in the second half of 2017? Or would you expect it to continue to decelerate?
componenttext: So following up on that deceleration comments about same-store revenue throughout 2017, would you expect it to stabilize in the second half of 2017? Or would you expect it to continue to decelerate?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: We would expect it to stabilize in 2017 in the second half. And again, the rate of deceleration has slowed. You're not seeing it drop a significant amount quarter-over-quarter, but we are estimating that we'll continue to decline slightly throughout the y
componenttext: We would expect it to stabilize in 2017 in the second half. And again, the rate of deceleration has slowed. You're not seeing it drop a significant amount quarter-over-quarter, but we are estimating that we'll continue to decline slightly throughout the year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think in your prepared remarks you mentioned that you are seeing reacceleration in some MSAs. Can you talk about which MSAs those are? And do you expect that to be sustainable?
componenttext: Okay. And I think in your prepared remarks you mentioned that you are seeing reacceleration in some MSAs. Can you talk about which MSAs those are? And do you expect that to be sustainable?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, the examples I would point you to, in particular, Chicago, Denver and Philadelphia. All 3 markets have seen reacceleration. Denver, in our same-store pool, was slightly negative, but in the bigger pool, it was positive and it's come back from being n
componenttext: Yes, the examples I would point you to, in particular, Chicago, Denver and Philadelphia. All 3 markets have seen reacceleration. Denver, in our same-store pool, was slightly negative, but in the bigger pool, it was positive and it's come back from being negative.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Todd Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just following up on the revenue growth guidance. What's in the model for effective move-in rates? How are discounts and pre-rent trending? And then what's in the model?
componenttext: Just following up on the revenue growth guidance. What's in the model for effective move-in rates? How are discounts and pre-rent trending? And then what's in the model?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Discounts are up slightly year-over-year, but it's probably a little bit more in line with your rate growth. So if your rates are up 3% to 5%, your discounts are automatically going to be up 3% to 5%, but they're up slightly above that and not a significa
componenttext: Discounts are up slightly year-over-year, but it's probably a little bit more in line with your rate growth. So if your rates are up 3% to 5%, your discounts are automatically going to be up 3% to 5%, but they're up slightly above that and not a significant effect. So it's mainly coming from rate this year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And in terms of new supply, I mean, can you talk about your appetite for CofO deals and lease-up properties here? Maybe just give us a sense for how large the 2017, '18 and '19 pipelines might be for Extra Space?
componenttext: Okay. And in terms of new supply, I mean, can you talk about your appetite for CofO deals and lease-up properties here? Maybe just give us a sense for how large the 2017, '18 and '19 pipelines might be for Extra Space?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: As we get deeper into the development cycle, we become increasingly more selective for CofO deals. As I said earlier, there are some markets that if we can find deals where there's barriers to entry and no or limited new supply and we're getting compensat
componenttext: As we get deeper into the development cycle, we become increasingly more selective for CofO deals. As I said earlier, there are some markets that if we can find deals where there's barriers to entry and no or limited new supply and we're getting compensated, we would certainly look at that deal. I would think the pace of our investments in CofO deals will moderate probably significantly, but we're very comfortable with the deals we've had. We've done very full due diligence. We've underwritten them conservatively. And performance to date has proven that out if you look at how our stores performed. We also have a target cap of 3% on the amount of dilution CofO stores will, in aggregate, contribute or detract from our performance, so we want to keep within that cap. And then the last thing I'd point out with respect to our appetite for CofO is we've executed a number of these deals in joint venture format, which both reduces the risk to us and increases our returns.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just, lastly, looking at a couple of other markets and just thinking about the occupancy, year-over-year decrease that you've seen portfolio-wide, but looking at some of the other markets like Boston, L.A., San Francisco, some of your top market
componenttext: Okay. And just, lastly, looking at a couple of other markets and just thinking about the occupancy, year-over-year decrease that you've seen portfolio-wide, but looking at some of the other markets like Boston, L.A., San Francisco, some of your top markets, occupancy's lower year-over-year and that year-over-year negative spread actually grew larger in the quarter, worsened a little bit. Are you thinking about occupancy differently than you have in the past as you think about maximizing revenue? Or is occupancy coming down as a result of new supply in these markets? What's sort of happening here?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think it's market by market. California had a really tough comp the prior year. I would tell you we're not necessarily thinking any differently in terms of occupancy. It's obviously important in our model to drive revenue, but I would tell you we lost a
componenttext: I think it's market by market. California had a really tough comp the prior year. I would tell you we're not necessarily thinking any differently in terms of occupancy. It's obviously important in our model to drive revenue, but I would tell you we lost a little bit of occupancy, but we kept some rate. So the fact that our street rates are up 3% to 4% is a good thing. Our bottom line is to grow revenue and occupancy is a big part of that. It's possible that going forward into the new year, our budgets and our guidance assumes that we spend a little bit more marketing also.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Do you think about that sort of slowing towards the long-term average from here and stabilizing starting in the back half of the year? In terms of some of your markets where revenues and NOI have moved negative or even just below the larger portfolio aver
componenttext: Do you think about that sort of slowing towards the long-term average from here and stabilizing starting in the back half of the year? In terms of some of your markets where revenues and NOI have moved negative or even just below the larger portfolio average, have you seen anything in particular from revenue management to give you confidence in your ability to react faster and therefore, recover quicker back to that long-term average? Or even just stabilize that average versus moving below the long-term average, which is something that I think a lot of people wonder about and worry about?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're consistently trying to improve the inputs to our revenue management system and its ability to both react and predict market conditions and how to optimize revenue in that. So I think we'd be the first to say that last year, in Denver, our reaction w
componenttext: We're consistently trying to improve the inputs to our revenue management system and its ability to both react and predict market conditions and how to optimize revenue in that. So I think we'd be the first to say that last year, in Denver, our reaction was not optimal and we've learned from that and we continue to try to improve.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So some of what you've learned from Denver is actually already playing out and then helping overall in terms of what's going on in the current portfolio. That's fair?
componenttext: Okay. So some of what you've learned from Denver is actually already playing out and then helping overall in terms of what's going on in the current portfolio. That's fair?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, yes.
componenttext: Absolutely, yes.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: I believe so. I don't want to ever say that our learning is done and we'll continue to try to make this machine better and make sure that when it doesn't work this year, we'd input, but yes, we're better than we were last year.
componenttext: I believe so. I don't want to ever say that our learning is done and we'll continue to try to make this machine better and make sure that when it doesn't work this year, we'd input, but yes, we're better than we were last year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, Scott, in terms of longer-term funding plans, you have the $400 million of investment activity in guidance plus call it another $200 million to $300 million of debt maturing, you obviously have room on the line, some capacity from t
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, Scott, in terms of longer-term funding plans, you have the $400 million of investment activity in guidance plus call it another $200 million to $300 million of debt maturing, you obviously have room on the line, some capacity from the unsecured notes you issued in October that you talked about in your opening remark. I think you still have a couple hundred million on the ATMs. I'm just wondering what's baked in the guidance in terms of further capital raises, if anything, and then just longer-term funding plans for some of the activity.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, our guidance assumes $100 million of OP or some type of equity. We've just included in there as OP. And then from there, it assumes that the rest is with debt. And if you look at the growth in NOI, I would tell you our ratios remain the same. So we'r
componenttext: Yes, our guidance assumes $100 million of OP or some type of equity. We've just included in there as OP. And then from there, it assumes that the rest is with debt. And if you look at the growth in NOI, I would tell you our ratios remain the same. So we're not looking to lever up and we'll look to remain -- keep our leverage ratios similar to where they are today.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gwen Clark with Evercore.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gwen Clark with Evercore.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Going back to rate growth, I think you said it should be up 3% to 5% for the total pool. Can you talk about what your expectation would be for the 2015 acquisitions such as SmartStop?
componenttext: Going back to rate growth, I think you said it should be up 3% to 5% for the total pool. Can you talk about what your expectation would be for the 2015 acquisitions such as SmartStop?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, they will be higher than that, but you're going to grow your revenue at those -- in that portfolio from a combination of rate as well as occupancy. So if you think of street rates in a portfolio where you're trying to push occupancy, you'll get more
componenttext: Yes, they will be higher than that, but you're going to grow your revenue at those -- in that portfolio from a combination of rate as well as occupancy. So if you think of street rates in a portfolio where you're trying to push occupancy, you'll get more from occupancy than you will from street rates, and you'll also get more from moving your existing customers up to the current market rates. So it's going to be a little bit different in terms of mix, but I would say, overall, that's why I'm saying 3% to 5% and that's obviously a range depending on market conditions, but SmartStop will get more through occupancy and more from existing customers than the other pool.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right, That's helpful. I guess moving on to a bigger-picture question, one of the questions that I feel like everyone's been asking is the trajectory for NOI growth and that was touched upon earlier. But can you talk about the scenario, which co
componenttext: Okay. All right, That's helpful. I guess moving on to a bigger-picture question, one of the questions that I feel like everyone's been asking is the trajectory for NOI growth and that was touched upon earlier. But can you talk about the scenario, which could actually drive overall same-store NOI growth negative in, say, 2018 or '19?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's tough to even fathom that. I think that from our perspective, the only time we've ever been negative was in the Great Recession. It's a recession that was bigger than I think most people are going to see in their lives and we were, call it, 3% negati
componenttext: It's tough to even fathom that. I think that from our perspective, the only time we've ever been negative was in the Great Recession. It's a recession that was bigger than I think most people are going to see in their lives and we were, call it, 3% negative in 2009. And then we were positive first quarter the next year. Now today's not the exact same market as that, but I would tell you I think it's going to take a pretty big event for everything to be negative for the year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it seems like it'd be fair to say that the new supply, which is probably going to hit in '18 isn't really enough in your mind to drive it like to a hard landing of negative growth?
componenttext: Okay. So it seems like it'd be fair to say that the new supply, which is probably going to hit in '18 isn't really enough in your mind to drive it like to a hard landing of negative growth?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: It's really hard to say what the level of new supply that's going to hit in '18 and '19 is. I would tell you that if there is continued delivery of new supply, it probably means industry remains pretty healthy.
componenttext: It's really hard to say what the level of new supply that's going to hit in '18 and '19 is. I would tell you that if there is continued delivery of new supply, it probably means industry remains pretty healthy.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jonathan Hughes with Raymond James.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk about the level of demand you're seeing in January? One of your peers mentioned they had really strong start to the year and a home builder this morning mentioned they've seen a release of pent-up demand for housing. I'm just curious i
componenttext: Could you just talk about the level of demand you're seeing in January? One of your peers mentioned they had really strong start to the year and a home builder this morning mentioned they've seen a release of pent-up demand for housing. I'm just curious if you're seeing a similar trend of increased demand so far this year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't really comment on what our peers have seen, but I can say that we have seen demand to be relatively flat. It's stable.
componenttext: Yes, I can't really comment on what our peers have seen, but I can say that we have seen demand to be relatively flat. It's stable.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no outsized growth in the first 6 weeks of the year?
componenttext: Okay. So no outsized growth in the first 6 weeks of the year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Nothing significant.
componenttext: Nothing significant.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one more for me. One of your competitors quantified the impact of new store openings on projected revenue growth at about 200 to 250 basis points below the portfolio average. Does your guidance include similar impact at stores exposed
componenttext: Okay. And then just one more for me. One of your competitors quantified the impact of new store openings on projected revenue growth at about 200 to 250 basis points below the portfolio average. Does your guidance include similar impact at stores exposed to new supply?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our guidance includes the impact of stores that are being added. So I can't comment on what they're seeing, but we have taken into account where we have a new store coming online near one of our existing stores.
componenttext: Our guidance includes the impact of stores that are being added. So I can't comment on what they're seeing, but we have taken into account where we have a new store coming online near one of our existing stores.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ryan Burke with Green Street Advisors.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on the development pipeline. Joe, your comments earlier about slowing development probably as we move forward do contrast a little bit with the fact that the development pipeline increased in size pretty meaningfully this quarte
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on the development pipeline. Joe, your comments earlier about slowing development probably as we move forward do contrast a little bit with the fact that the development pipeline increased in size pretty meaningfully this quarter. Can you reconcile those 2 dynamics? And then second question is just scanning the 2018 projected openings. It does seem like there's a greater percentage of properties that are located in, I don't want to call them secondary markets perhaps, but maybe nonmajor metro areas.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, I -- sorry, finish your question first.
componenttext: Yes, I -- sorry, finish your question first.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just curious if the strategy there, if it is a strategy or it just happens to be the outcome of what was available?
componenttext: Just curious if the strategy there, if it is a strategy or it just happens to be the outcome of what was available?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would tell you the jump in the pipeline comes from us putting certain properties now under contract that we're doing with the joint venture partner in a couple of areas of the country, one is in the Northwest and the other one is in the New Jersey
componenttext: Yes. I would tell you the jump in the pipeline comes from us putting certain properties now under contract that we're doing with the joint venture partner in a couple of areas of the country, one is in the Northwest and the other one is in the New Jersey kind of New York City down to Philadelphia markets, and those are all joint ventures that we've been discussing and looking at for a year to 2 years and they actually just went under contract this quarter. And so we've had the kind of the policy or the standing that we don't want to talk about them unless they're under contract. So this was just kind of an odd quarter where many of those went under contract even though we've been talking about those for a long time.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the pipeline's kind of in place. But if things play out the think -- the way that you think they might in terms of operating fundamentals, et cetera, we should expect the pipeline to not grow significantly for the out-years beyond 2018?
componenttext: Okay. So the pipeline's kind of in place. But if things play out the think -- the way that you think they might in terms of operating fundamentals, et cetera, we should expect the pipeline to not grow significantly for the out-years beyond 2018?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think that's correct. That -- my comments about increasing selectivity for future years is -- that's what I was trying to drive at.
componenttext: I think that's correct. That -- my comments about increasing selectivity for future years is -- that's what I was trying to drive at.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Wes Golladay with RBC.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Looking at the expansion projects, where are those located? And do you have much more of those planned for this year?
componenttext: Looking at the expansion projects, where are those located? And do you have much more of those planned for this year?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: So we have a few of those, one is on Long Island, we have one in Chicago, one in Salt Lake City are kind of the bigger ones. And we have ongoing expansions all the time. This was an odd one. Typically, you pull them out of your same-store group, but they
componenttext: So we have a few of those, one is on Long Island, we have one in Chicago, one in Salt Lake City are kind of the bigger ones. And we have ongoing expansions all the time. This was an odd one. Typically, you pull them out of your same-store group, but they completed quicker than we expected and so part of that was just timing and we felt like rather than changing the same-store group in the fourth quarter, we would just leave them in and talk to it, but we always have expansions going on.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then trying to look at supply, I mean, how should we view it? I mean, we always talk about the nominal store count, but is there -- what do you see as a manageable supply level on a percentage of square foot -- or facilities? Is it like a 4% to
componenttext: Okay. And then trying to look at supply, I mean, how should we view it? I mean, we always talk about the nominal store count, but is there -- what do you see as a manageable supply level on a percentage of square foot -- or facilities? Is it like a 4% to 5%, you mentioned the pent-up demand. Are there any markets where there's large clusters that you're concerned about and the other markets you're like that is not a big deal? How should we view it from a, I guess, from the cluster point of view?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes. And so overall, I would tell you on a national level, I think that equal to population growth is healthy and you've got to look at square footage versus store count because stores today are being built bigger than they were before. I think that there
componenttext: Yes. And so overall, I would tell you on a national level, I think that equal to population growth is healthy and you've got to look at square footage versus store count because stores today are being built bigger than they were before. I think that there are certain markets we're clearly concerned about and watching closely and there's other markets where you just have not seen supply come. On the West Coast, California has seen very little new supply compared to the population, Texas has seen fair amount, Atlanta. Anywhere where it's easy to entitle things, you've seen supply.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And would it be fair to say that you're going to try and expand more in supply-constrained markets? Is that where you guys would target those?
componenttext: Okay. And would it be fair to say that you're going to try and expand more in supply-constrained markets? Is that where you guys would target those?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. I mean, from our perspective, you're always going to look for low saturation population per square foot -- per square foot per population.
componenttext: Absolutely. I mean, from our perspective, you're always going to look for low saturation population per square foot -- per square foot per population.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Todd Stender with Wells Fargo.

componenttext: So it goes in January 1, 2017. It's in there and that's what's causing the outsized growth. And compared to plan, it is performing a fair amount ahead of our underwriting.

componenttext: In the presentation, we've bifurcated. Going forward, it goes into our same-store pool this year so 2017. And I guess, that it continues to outperform our underwriting.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017

componenttext: Okay. And just get an update maybe on paid search costs as much detail as you can on how much you're budgeting for Google search this year and maybe any changes in strategy as you head into the spring leasing season?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, our budgets assume a 6% increase in marketing, which, last year, we were actually down slightly. So it's a tough comp it's up against. But cost, we continue to try to be more effective and more efficient, but reality is as more people are bidding, so
componenttext: Yes, our budgets assume a 6% increase in marketing, which, last year, we were actually down slightly. So it's a tough comp it's up against. But cost, we continue to try to be more effective and more efficient, but reality is as more people are bidding, so costs are going up. So we need to try to keep the cost for acquisition down.

componenttext: So Google rates going up are just -- there's more people bidding, which drives the rates up. Utilization, people use paid search consistently. So we found it's a good way to drive traffic. We'll continue to spend money on paid search.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: I can tell you how we react and I would tell you that, that depends on a little bit of velocity. So if the store comes in and, for instance, we opened a store in Venice, California. The store filled up in 6 months. I would tell you a store that competes w
componenttext: I can tell you how we react and I would tell you that, that depends on a little bit of velocity. So if the store comes in and, for instance, we opened a store in Venice, California. The store filled up in 6 months. I would tell you a store that competes with that store shouldn't have done anything. They should have just weathered the storm. So typically, when we opened a new store, a CofO store, we'll open it with rates 10% to 20% below market and we'll discount every single rental. So it really depends on velocity, lease-up velocity, when you make a decision on what you're going to do with the store.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: So street rate changes I would tell you are just one of the factors in the model. If you want to drive occupancy, the way you drive occupancy is you lower rates, you increase paid search spend and you increase discounts. So it's just one of the levers. So
componenttext: So street rate changes I would tell you are just one of the factors in the model. If you want to drive occupancy, the way you drive occupancy is you lower rates, you increase paid search spend and you increase discounts. So it's just one of the levers. So it's going to depend obviously on your occupancy and your revenue growth. It's just one of the factors in that.

componenttextpreview: First, what is the premium to move-out above move-in, in the fourth quarter? And then what are you seeing in January?
componenttext: First, what is the premium to move-out above move-in, in the fourth quarter? And then what are you seeing in January?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 22, 2017
componenttextpreview: Yes, so if you look at our -- when we talk about premium on move-outs, we don't talk about the rent roll-down. What we're talking about is our average in-place rent compared to our average street rate. And I would tell you that on average for the year, it
componenttext: Yes, so if you look at our -- when we talk about premium on move-outs, we don't talk about the rent roll-down. What we're talking about is our average in-place rent compared to our average street rate. And I would tell you that on average for the year, it's mid to high single digits depending on the time of the year. So in other words, when we're raising rates in the summer, that roll-down or that negative mark is lower. But everybody does not move out in equal -- what I'm saying is you have more churn. Our median length of stay is 6 to 7 months, but our average length of stay is 14 months. So you have a group of units that are constantly churning that have a very short length of stay. So many of those customers never received a rate increase or received one rate increase and some of those moved in below street rates. So when they move out, it's actually very little impact and also you have a large number of those that churn all the time. So our negative mark-to-market is different than our in-place rents compared to our street rates.

componenttext: You guys had commented for probably about 24 months now that the pace of lease-up development in your CofO deals are well ahead of long-term trend. Are you seeing you that abate at all? Or is lease-up still very -- the pace is pretty aggressive? I mean, just given the supply -- new supply coming on, are you seeing those time lines elongate?

componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. So the earliest CofOs we delivered leased up within a year most of them, just way ahead of historical norms in underwriting. The more recent deals are leasing up between 1 and 2 years on average. So certainly, the pace of leas
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. So the earliest CofOs we delivered leased up within a year most of them, just way ahead of historical norms in underwriting. The more recent deals are leasing up between 1 and 2 years on average. So certainly, the pace of lease-up has slowed down, but we've underwritten all these deals at 36 to 42 months. So they're not leasing up as fast as they were, but they're still leasing up generally ahead of projections.

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage Inc. First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Jeff Norman, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. Please remember that management's prepared remarks and
componenttext:
Thank you, James. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website. 
Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review. Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, April 27, 2017. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Joe Margolis, Chief Executive Officer

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. We kicked off 2017 with a solid first quarter and fundamentals remain positive. We gained occupancy, grew street rates and increased same-store revenue by 5.8%. We demonstrated great expense control with a 2% decrease in same-store expens
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. We kicked off 2017 with a solid first quarter and fundamentals remain positive. We gained occupancy, grew street rates and increased same-store revenue by 5.8%. We demonstrated great expense control with a 2% decrease in same-store expenses. As a result, same-store NOI grew 9.2%, and FFO per share as adjusted increased by 20%. We saw positive year-over-year revenue growth in all MSAs. We also saw acceleration of revenue growth in several MSAs, including Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia, demonstrating the cyclical nature of markets. We are enjoying the benefits of a well-balanced, diversified portfolio, operational scale and the ability to achieve outsized growth from stores added to our platform. We continue to be disciplined on the acquisition front, and we are committed to transact only at prices that will provide long-term value for our shareholders. 
During the quarter, we added 2 wholly-owned storage and 2 joint venture storage for a total investment of $28 million. 
In the quarter, we added 27 new properties to our third-party platform, and we have a robust pipeline of additional storage, which we will manage under the Extra Space brand. These managed storage will provide us additional fee income, density in key markets, customer data and potential future acquisition opportunities. Importantly, we are starting to see a more balanced mix of development and existing stores in our managed store pipeline. 
I would now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.03 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.04. Revenues were in line with expectations, and the beat was primarily driven by property operating expenses. Property taxes and payroll
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.03 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.04. Revenues were in line with expectations, and the beat was primarily driven by property operating expenses. Property taxes and payroll were lower than expected, and utilities and snow removal were below budget due to a mild winter. 
Our 2017 same-store pool increased by 168 stores for a total of 732. The change in the same-store pool added 110 basis points to revenue growth in the quarter, and we expect to benefit from the change in pool to average 50 basis points over the year. 
Same-store NOI benefited 220 basis points from the change in pool during the quarter. 
Beginning January 1, 2017, we have elected to exclude revenue and expenses related to connect reinsurance from our same-store numbers. This quarter, we are presenting the impact of this change in our Q1 supplemental financial information, which shows the results of our 2016 and 2017 same-store pools with and without [indiscernible] reinsurance. 
Occupancy for the same-store pool ended the quarter at 92.2% with an 80 basis point year-over-year increase. We are -- we were able to push our rates to new customers approximately 3% to 4% during the quarter. We experienced positive net rentals each month and continue to see steady demand. 
In the first quarter, we did not access our ATM. Acquisitions and loan maturities were funded by draws on our credit facility. At quarter end, we have drawn $300 million on the term loans with $350 million in remaining term debt available. The revolving portion of the credit facility had a balance of $337 million with $163 million available. Subsequent to quarter end, we swapped $300 million from fixed to variable -- from variable rate to fixed rate debt on a 5-year term tranche. 
We reaffirm our annual same-store revenue guidance of 4% to 5%. Due to the Q1 expense beat, we are lowering our annual expense guidance to 2.25% to 3.25%. As a result, we are increasing our annual NOI guidance to 4.25% to 5.75%. We also reaffirm our original acquisition guidance of total investment of $400 million. The mix has changed slightly and now includes $325 million in wholly-owned stores and $190 million in joint venture acquisitions and developments, with approximately $75 million in capital to be contributed by Extra Space. Approximately $150 million is currently closed or identified. Our guidance assumes the remaining unidentified acquisitions will close in the third and fourth quarter. 
As a result of the Q1 beat, we are increasing our full year FFO as adjusted guidance to $4.21 to $4.29 per share. Our guidance includes $0.07 of dilution from our CofO stores and an additional $0.08 from value-add acquisitions for a total of $0.15. 
I'll now turn the time back to Joe.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. We had a solid first quarter with growth in rates, rentals and occupancy, and we are well-positioned heading into our busy season. Revenue deacceleration from our core assets continues to flatten. We are seeing great performance from val
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. We had a solid first quarter with growth in rates, rentals and occupancy, and we are well-positioned heading into our busy season. Revenue deacceleration from our core assets continues to flatten. We are seeing great performance from value-added acquisitions as they are integrated onto our platform. While we expect moderation in the back half of the year, we still expect stores to produce some of the best revenue growth in the real estate sector. We continue to monitor new supply in key markets to analyze its impact on our performance and to adjust operations at affected stores to minimize impact. While certain stores and markets have felt the impact of new development, it has not prevented us from experiencing positive revenue growth. Also, we are seeing reacceleration of revenue growth in some markets, including some that were on the front end of the development cycle. 
In addition to maximizing same-store operating performance, we continue to utilize other tools that enhance FFO. We are focused on building our third-party management portfolio and pursuing high-yielding redevelopment and expansion opportunities at our existing stores. Such efforts, together with our solid operations, should lead to another strong year of FFO growth. 
Let's now turn it back over to Jeff to start the Q&A session

componenttext: Just in terms of how you're looking at acquisitions for the rest of the year and what would have to happen to sort of change acquisition volume, I mean, obviously, a better stock price would help. componenttextpreview: We're not pricing acquisitions on our stock price on any particular day. Our stock price is going to go up or down. I have no idea when our stock price goes up and down. And we're trying to find acquisitions that produce long-term value for our shareholde
componenttext: We're not pricing acquisitions on our stock price on any particular day. Our stock price is going to go up or down. I have no idea when our stock price goes up and down. And we're trying to find acquisitions that produce long-term value for our shareholders without kind of comparing it to spot pricing of our stock. What we're looking and hoping to happen so we can acquire more properties at the back end of the year is that cap rates expand and sellers expectations for pricing are more in line with what we are willing to pay for properties.

componenttextpreview: So in 2016, the vast majority of projects that we signed up for and the people were inquiring about to have us manage these stores from were new developments. And now are starting to see more existing owners, I think, as the going gets a little tougher, r
componenttext: So in 2016, the vast majority of projects that we signed up for and the people were inquiring about to have us manage these stores from were new developments. And now are starting to see more existing owners, I think, as the going gets a little tougher, realize they need professional management and we're having with more discussions with existing owners. 40% of the properties we brought on in the first quarter were existing properties. And that's important because when you bring an existing property on, we start making money right away because it's full and our fee is a percentage of revenue. And when you bring on development property, it's not as profitable until you can lease it up.

componenttext: Yes. If you look at the first quarter and how we performed, quarter versus our budget, I would tell you our property taxes came in lower than we expected. We -- our property taxes beat our budgets by about $1.2 million and about -- just over half of that was the result of either appeals that where we had favorable outcomes or adjustment to existing accruals on the SmartStop and the other assure portfolios with properties in Texas and Illinois. When we bought the properties, we used property tax consultants to accrue on those for the first year, a year and a half now. And those 2 states report on a lag. When we got the final bills, we ended up reversing of accruals [indiscernible] $0.5 million. So we would tell you that those are benefits that we don't expect to see throughout the year. We also had some benefit from payroll versus our budget, but we think we're still early in the year and it's probably a little bit too early to see whether or not that's going to continue throughout the year.

componenttext: Okay, thanks. And then just a bigger picture question on this revenue growth as you look out. It's about $175 million worth of projects, double-digit returns, and we'll continue to try to push more projects into that pipeline. componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Extra Space Storage Inc. First Quarter 2017 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Jeff Norman, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.Please remember that management's prepared remarks and a
componenttext:
Thank you, James. Welcome to Extra Space Storage's First Quarter 2017 Earnings Call. In addition to our press release, we have furnished unaudited supplemental financial information on our website.
Please remember that management's prepared remarks and answers to your questions may contain forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act. Actual results could differ materially from those stated or implied by our forward-looking statements due to risks and uncertainties associated with the company's business. These forward-looking statements are qualified by the cautionary statements contained in the company's latest filings with the SEC, which we encourage our listeners to review. Forward-looking statements represent management's estimates as of today, Thursday, April 27, 2017. The company assumes no obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements because of changing market conditions or other circumstances after the date of this conference call.
I would now like to turn the call over to Joe Margolis, Chief Executive Officer.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Hello, everyone. We kicked off 2017 with a solid first quarter, and fundamentals remain positive. We gained occupancy, grew street rates and increased same-store revenue by 5.8%. We demonstrated great expense control with a 2% decrease in same-store expen
componenttext:
Hello, everyone. We kicked off 2017 with a solid first quarter, and fundamentals remain positive. We gained occupancy, grew street rates and increased same-store revenue by 5.8%. We demonstrated great expense control with a 2% decrease in same-store expenses. As a result, same-store NOI grew 9.2%, and FFO per share as adjusted increased by 20%. We saw positive year-over-year revenue growth in all MSAs. We also saw acceleration of revenue growth in several MSAs, including Boston, Chicago and Philadelphia, demonstrating the cyclical nature of markets. We are enjoying the benefits of a well-balanced, diversified portfolio, operational scale and the ability to achieve outsized growth from stores added to our platform. We continue to be disciplined on the acquisition front, and we are committed to transact only at prices that will provide long-term value for our shareholders.
During the quarter, we added 2 wholly-owned stores and 2 joint venture stores for a total investment of $28 million.
In the quarter, we added 27 new properties to our third-party platform, and we have a robust pipeline of additional stores, which we will manage under the Extra Space brand. These managed stores will provide us additional fee income, density in key markets, customer data and potential future acquisition opportunities. Importantly, we are starting to see a more balanced mix of development and existing stores in our managed store pipeline.
I would now like to turn the time over to Scott.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.03 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.04. Revenues were in line with expectations, and the beat was primarily driven by property operating expenses. Property taxes and payroll
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Last night, we reported FFO as adjusted of $1.03 per share, exceeding the high end of our guidance by $0.04. Revenues were in line with expectations, and the beat was primarily driven by property operating expenses. Property taxes and payroll were lower than expected, and utilities and snow removal were below budget due to a mild winter.
Our 2017 same-store pool increased by 168 stores for a total of 732. The change in the same-store pool added 110 basis points to revenue growth in the quarter, and we expect to benefit from the change in pool to average 50 basis points over the year.
Same-store NOI benefited 220 basis points from the change in pool during the quarter.
Beginning January 1, 2017, we have elected to exclude revenue and expenses related to tenant reinsurance from our same-store numbers. This quarter, we are presenting the impact of this change in our Q1 supplemental financial information, which shows the results of our 2016 and 2017 same-store pools with and without tenant reinsurance.
Occupancy for the same-store pool ended the quarter at 92.2% with an 80 basis point year-over-year increase. We were able to push our rates to new customers approximately 3% to 4% during the quarter. We experienced positive net rentals each month and continue to see steady demand.
In the first quarter, we did not access our ATM. Acquisitions and loan maturities were funded by draws on our credit facility. At quarter end, we have drawn $300 million on the term loans with $350 million in remaining term debt available. The revolving portion of the credit facility had a balance of $337 million with $163 million available. Subsequent to quarter end, we swapped $300 million from fixed to variable -- from variable rate to fixed rate debt on a 5-year term tranche.
We reaffirm our annual same-store revenue guidance of 4% to 5%. Due to the Q1 expense beat, we are lowering our annual expense guidance to 2.25% to 3.25%. As a result, we are increasing our annual NOI guidance to 4.25% to 5.75%. We also reaffirm our original acquisition guidance of total investment of $400 million. The mix has changed slightly and now includes $325 million in wholly-owned stores and $190 million in joint venture acquisitions and developments, with approximately $75 million in capital to be contributed by Extra Space. Approximately $150 million is currently closed or identified. Our guidance assumes the remaining unidentified acquisitions will close in the third and fourth quarter.
As a result of the Q1 beat, we are increasing our full year FFO as adjusted guidance to $4.21 to $4.29 per share. Our guidance includes $0.07 of dilution from our CofO stores and an additional $0.08 from value-add acquisitions for a total of $0.15.
I'll now turn the time back to Joe.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. We had a solid first quarter with growth in rates, rentals and occupancy, and we are well positioned heading into our busy season. Revenue deceleration from our core assets continues to flatten. We are seeing great performance from value
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. We had a solid first quarter with growth in rates, rentals and occupancy, and we are well positioned heading into our busy season. Revenue deceleration from our core assets continues to flatten. We are seeing great performance from value-added acquisitions as they are integrated onto our platform. While we expect moderation in the back half of the year, we still expect stores to produce some of the best revenue growth in the real estate sector. We continue to monitor new supply in key markets to analyze its impact on our performance and to adjust operations at affected stores to minimize impact. While certain stores and markets have felt the impact of new development, it has not prevented us from experiencing positive revenue growth. Also, we are seeing reacceleration of revenue growth in some markets, including some that were on the front end of the development cycle.
In addition to maximizing same-store operating performance, we continue to utilize other tools that enhance FFO. We are focused on building our third-party management portfolio and pursuing high-yielding redevelopment and expansion opportunities at our existing stores. Such efforts, together with our solid operations, should lead to another strong year of FFO growth.
Let's now turn the time over to Jeff to start the Q&A session.

Denver is another one, maybe not to the extent of Chicago. And I would just caution you, we're not saying it's a hockey stick, but we're saying we're moving in the right direction.

componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then I just wanted to ask you quickly, you had mentioned on your last call that the visibility into '18 supply was difficult to get a good feel for. And I'm just wondering a few months more into the year, do you have a better feel for whe
componenttext: Okay, great. And then I just wanted to ask you quickly, you had mentioned on your last call that the visibility into '18 supply was difficult to get a good feel for. And I'm just wondering a few months more into the year, do you have a better feel for where supply might end up in 2018?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: I think that's a very difficult question. I mean, storage as a property type has a very short delivery cycle. You can build these stores relatively quickly. And we're continuing to see a significant, up to 60% fallout rate in the development projects that
componenttext: I think that's a very difficult question. I mean, storage as a property type has a very short delivery cycle. You can build these stores relatively quickly. And we're continuing to see a significant, up to 60% fallout rate in the development projects that are in our ManagementPlus pipeline. And as unsatisfactory as an answer this is, I think that leads you to believe that there is not great visibility into next year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Joe, would you -- it's Michael Bilerman speaking. How do you think about, PSA will talk about what the public REITs are doing and extrapolate that based on the public market shares -- share of the industry. So they would take the 5.25, 5.3 that's being de
componenttext: Joe, would you -- it's Michael Bilerman speaking. How do you think about, PSA will talk about what the public REITs are doing and extrapolate that based on the public market shares -- share of the industry. So they would take the 5.25, 5.3 that's being developed by the public REITs, take 13% and say there's 45 million, 46 million square feet of development. I guess, how would you look at it overall? Do you think that over, under estimates or is an accurate estimate of the amount of supply that's coming online?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: I have great respect for Ron and Public Storage, but I don't know the assumption that the percentage that the publics are developing versus the overall market will give you an accurate read.
componenttext: I have great respect for Ron and Public Storage, but I don't know the assumption that the percentage that the publics are developing versus the overall market will give you an accurate read.

componenttext: Yes. This is Scott. I will tell you the street rates grew -- street and achieved rates grew at 3% to 4% in the quarter. That continues into April. And I would tell you the SmartStop rates are actually probably slightly lower than that as we continue to gain occupancy at those properties. But it's been steady at the 3% to 4%.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then what should we think of as driving the deceleration in the SmartStop contribution that you said you're holding the 50 basis point contribution to same-store revenue for the year? Is that just filling up the stores and having kind of less low-hanging fruit?

componenttext: Tougher comps. You're coming up against -- it was already performing very well in the back half of last year. And as this year compares to the back half of last year, those comps get tougher.

componenttext: It's ticked up slightly, but I wouldn't put too much credence in that. It's been pretty steady at between 40% and 60% over last year.

componenttext: Our next question comes from George Hoglund of Jefferies.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Just in terms of how you're looking at acquisitions for the rest of the year and what would have to happen to sort of change acquisition volume, I mean, obviously, a better stock price would help. But in terms of kind of where pricing is today, where your
componenttext: Just in terms of how you're looking at acquisitions for the rest of the year and what would have to happen to sort of change acquisition volume, I mean, obviously, a better stock price would help. But in terms of kind of where pricing is today, where your stock is, how much the Delta is there between kind of where pricing is and where it would have to be to get you guys more active?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: We're not pricing acquisitions on our stock price on any particular day. Our stock price is going to go up or down. I have no idea why our stock price goes up and down. And we're trying to find acquisitions that produce long-term value for our shareholder
componenttext: We're not pricing acquisitions on our stock price on any particular day. Our stock price is going to go up or down. I have no idea why our stock price goes up and down. And we're trying to find acquisitions that produce long-term value for our shareholders without kind of comparing it to spot pricing of our stock. What we're looking and hoping to happen so we can acquire more properties at the back end of the year is that cap rates expand and sellers' expectations for pricing are more in line with what we're willing to pay for properties.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017

componenttext: And any sort of general sense kind of ballpark sort of on a cap rate basis, ROE 50, 100 bps away or how far?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's probably a pretty fair range.
componenttext: Yes, I think that's probably a pretty fair range.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Would you mind just elaborating a little bit further just to explain what you mean and why it's important, notable?
componenttext: Would you mind just elaborating a little bit further just to explain what you mean and why it's important, notable?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: So in 2016, the vast majority of projects that we signed up for and the people were inquiring about to have us manage these stores from were new developments. And now we're starting to see more existing owners, I think, as the going gets a little tougher,
componenttext: So in 2016, the vast majority of projects that we signed up for and the people were inquiring about to have us manage these stores from were new developments. And now we're starting to see more existing owners, I think, as the going gets a little tougher, realize they need professional management. And we're having more and more discussions with existing owners. 40% of the properties we brought on in the first quarter were existing properties. And that's important because when you bring an existing property on, we start making money right away because it's full, and our fee is a percentage of revenue. And when you bring on development property, it's not as profitable until you can lease it up.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, makes sense. There has been some talk of smaller developers potentially becoming a little bit uneasy about the operating environment and potentially looking to sell actually sooner than they otherwise would have. Are you guys seeing that?
componenttext: Okay, makes sense. There has been some talk of smaller developers potentially becoming a little bit uneasy about the operating environment and potentially looking to sell actually sooner than they otherwise would have. Are you guys seeing that?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're seeing enough of that, that we call that a trend.
componenttext: I don't think we're seeing enough of that, that we call that a trend.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017

componenttext: Last question. Any update on the potential disposition portfolio?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Sure. So to be clear, we're looking to recapitalize a portfolio to sell a majority interest in it or transfer to a JV in which we would own a minority interest, keep it under the Extra Space platform. We are undergoing a process. We've collected first rou
componenttext: Sure. So to be clear, we're looking to recapitalize a portfolio to sell a majority interest in it or transfer to a JV in which we would own a minority interest, keep it under the Extra Space platform. We are undergoing a process. We've collected first round bids, and we're in a process. And we'll talk more about it when we're done.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Are you able to provide any color about the likelihood of that being a new JV partner versus an existing partner?
componenttext: Are you able to provide any color about the likelihood of that being a new JV partner versus an existing partner?

componenttext: Really can't say until we know where we end up.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: First question is around this time last year, there's some softness in demand set in around the start of the peak leasing season. And I was just wondering if you could comment on how the beginning of the peak season has been so far here and if you're doin
componenttext: First question is around this time last year, there's some softness in demand set in around the start of the peak leasing season. And I was just wondering if you could comment on how the beginning of the peak season has been so far here and if you're doing anything differently this year having observed that softness last year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: So this year versus last year, I would tell you this year has been steady so far. Last year, we were probably a little bit more aggressive on pricing and year-over-year, we were not spending extra on the Internet. Our year-over-year marketing cost last ye
componenttext: So this year versus last year, I would tell you this year has been steady so far. Last year, we were probably a little bit more aggressive on pricing and year-over-year, we were not spending extra on the Internet. Our year-over-year marketing cost last year actually went down. This year, we're spending more. Our budgets are a little bit higher, so that potentially -- lower prices, higher marketing spend is yielding -- it's a good yield for us this year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. But you're not seeing market pricing or any increase in competition necessarily create softness so far at this point in the beginning of the peak leasing season?
componenttext: Okay. But you're not seeing market pricing or any increase in competition necessarily create softness so far at this point in the beginning of the peak leasing season?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Year-to-date, we have not. Our rentals, our demand has been steady to slightly up, and our rates are still 3% to 4% above where they were last year. So we'd classify that as a solid year.
componenttext: Year-to-date, we have not. Our rentals, our demand has been steady to slightly up, and our rates are still 3% to 4% above where they were last year. So we'd classify that as a solid year.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just following up on the impact from the SmartStop portfolio. So it sounds like you're expecting the year-over-year contribution to be fairly muted by year end, so essentially no benefit. Is that the right read? And is that what's embedded
componenttext: Okay. And then just following up on the impact from the SmartStop portfolio. So it sounds like you're expecting the year-over-year contribution to be fairly muted by year end, so essentially no benefit. Is that the right read? And is that what's embedded in guidance?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: That is correct, and that is what is embedded in guidance.
componenttext: That is correct, and that is what is embedded in guidance.

componenttext: Our next question comes from Gwen Clark with Evercore ISI.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Can you guys give us a rundown of how your largest markets fared relative to expectations and whether there were any surprises in the quarter?
componenttext: Can you guys give us a rundown of how your largest markets fared relative to expectations and whether there were any surprises in the quarter?

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: So first thing I would tell you is our markets -- in our supplementals, we disclosed 2 things. We disclosed our same-store and then also our mature pool. And I think that there is a little noise in both of those disclosures in the supplement in that Smart
componenttext: So first thing I would tell you is our markets -- in our supplementals, we disclosed 2 things. We disclosed our same-store and then also our mature pool. And I think that there is a little noise in both of those disclosures in the supplement in that SmartStop has been added to both of those pools as well as the larger Dallas acquisition, which we did last year. So a few of those markets could potentially be overstated as a result of adding those properties. I would tell you, Los Angeles continues to do well. Sacramento, to a lesser degree, continues to do well. It's had good growth for -- now this is onto the third year. I would tell you we would probably expect that to tail off. It's been 15-plus percent for a long period of time. Boston is not doing as well, but it has bounced back some. And then Houston and Dallas continue to slide a little bit.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Just one quick follow-up. On the topic of California, have you seen any signs that supply is going to pop up in the larger metro areas that you're in?

componenttext: So we're very focused on South Orange County and Irvine Company is very aggressively building. We're managing those stores, so we know, but there's a good amount of supply coming there. San Jose and San Diego are the 2 markets we're looking at.

componenttext: You mean in terms of supply coming on or you're looking to build?

componenttext: Right -- no. I'm sorry. I'm sorry to be unclear. San Jose and San Diego are 2 markets that there is some supply coming on, and we're looking at that and trying to understand it.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Jon Hughes with Raymond James.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017

componenttext: Same-store revenues were up 4% in the overall New York same-store pool. But could you tell us what the revenue growth was in the 61 assets that are in the old same-store pool?

componenttextpreview: Our New York market did not see a huge benefit or a huge difference between the 2 pools, so it was slightly less in the old same-store pool. We have seen a difference between New York, Northern New Jersey and the Boroughs. The Boroughs are not doing as we
componenttext: Our New York market did not see a huge benefit or a huge difference between the 2 pools, so it was slightly less in the old same-store pool. We have seen a difference between New York, Northern New Jersey and the Boroughs. The Boroughs are not doing as well. But we do not have as much exposure to the Boroughs, so we may not have enough exposure for it to be a good example size. But we are seeing slower growth in the Boroughs and better growth in Northern New Jersey and Long Island.

headline: Extra Space Storage Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2017
componenttextpreview: Okay. Appreciate that. And then why was vacate activity showed favorable during the quarter? I'm just curious to know if same-store rentals and vacates were materially different across the old same-store pool and the 170 assets added this year.
componenttext: Okay. Appreciate that. And then why was vacate activity showed favorable during the quarter? I'm just curious to know if same-store rentals and vacates were materially different across the old same-store pool and the 170 assets added this year.

componenttext: You're hard part, I would tell you, is you're always comparing to the prior year, and it depends a little bit on what happened last year. But I think that I wouldn't focus too much on year-over-year. But we did have a mild winter this year, but last winter was not terrible either so...
